articles.headline: Mexico’s Pride, Oil, May Be Opened to Outsiders
articles.snippet: Lawmakers are poised to open the oil, gas and electricity industry to private investment, testing the grip oil has had on Mexico’s soul.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers are poised to open the oil, gas and electricity industry to private investment, testing the grip oil has had on Mexico’s soul.
articles.lead_paragraph: CIUDAD DEL CARMEN, Mexico — Every gas station in Mexico is stamped with the green-and-white logo of the state-owned oil monopoly, the economic lifeblood of the government. Oil Expropriation Day, commemorating the day Mexico seized control of the industry from foreign companies in 1938, is celebrated with speeches and even parades in some towns. An old song, “The Oil Worker Hymn,” credits oil with “saving our fatherland.”
articles.byline: By Randal C. Archibold and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.headline: It’s Hard to Summon Sympathy for Big Banks
articles.snippet: Big banks have gone from being viewed as national champions — proof of a country’s standing in the world — to being seen as a potential source of national disaster.
articles.abstract: Big banks have gone from being viewed as national champions — proof of a country’s standing in the world — to being seen as a potential source of national disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s no fun to be a banker these days.

articles.headline: U.S. Agencies Dance Around Cellphone Use Aloft
articles.snippet: The Transportation Department is considering whether allowing in-flight voice calls is fair to consumers.
articles.abstract: The Transportation Department is considering whether allowing in-flight voice calls is fair to consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Transportation Department said on Thursday that it would consider banning the use of cellphones for voice calls aboard airplanes, a reaction to public outrage at a Federal Communications Commission proposal to lift a rule that has long forbidden the use of mobile phones during flight.

articles.headline: A Stream of Music, Not Revenue
articles.snippet: With download sales cooling after a decade of growth, streaming services like Spotify, Pandora and Apple’s new iTunes Radio have become the latest hope for the troubled music business.
articles.abstract: With download sales cooling after a decade of growth, streaming services like Spotify, Pandora and Apple’s new iTunes Radio have become the latest hope for the troubled music business.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Spotify, the digital music company of the moment, announced this week an exclusive deal with Led Zeppelin and free access on mobile devices, it also reported impressive numbers. Its listeners have streamed 4.5 billion hours of music this year, and it has paid more than $1 billion in music royalties since its founding.

articles.headline: A Surprise From Hilton: Big Profit for Blackstone
articles.snippet: From what looked like a sure loss during the financial crisis, Blackstone engineered one of the most successful deals in its history.
articles.abstract: From what looked like a sure loss during the financial crisis, Blackstone engineered one of the most successful deals in its history.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the topsy-turvy world of private equity math, what at first glance looks like a multibillion-dollar loss can in fact be a huge gain.

articles.headline: As Sales Lag, VW Picks a New Leader for U.S.
articles.snippet: American sales for the Volkswagen division have fallen 5.2 percent so far this year, to 374,000 vehicles, leading to the management change.
articles.abstract: American sales for the Volkswagen division have fallen 5.2 percent so far this year, to 374,000 vehicles, leading to the management change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Midway through an ambitious 10-year plan to become the world’s largest automaker, Volkswagen has hit a rough patch in the United States, with sales stagnating this year even as the rest of the industry has surged.

articles.headline: Obama Panel Said to Urge N.S.A. Curbs
articles.snippet: A presidential advisory committee’s recommendation of broad new restraints intended to increase privacy protections is a first sign that spying revelations may lead to changes.
articles.abstract: A presidential advisory committee’s recommendation of broad new restraints intended to increase privacy protections is a first sign that spying revelations may lead to changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A presidential advisory committee charged with examining the operations of the National Security Agency has concluded that a program to collect data on every phone call made in the United States should continue, though under broad new restraints that would be intended to increase privacy protections, according to officials with knowledge of the report’s contents.
